column4: What is the Constraint
Major Subjects (e.g., Maths, Science, Languages) should be scheduled every day.
For a specific class, a maximum of 2 minor subjects (e.g., Art, Music, Hobby) can be scheduled in a single day.
Single Timetable may have a different number of periods per day for different classes (e.g., Class 2 has 6 periods/day, Classes 3-12 have 8 periods/day).
Games, Library, Art, Hobby, Dance, and Music periods should not be scheduled on the same day for a given class.
Maths for class 4T should be allotted only in periods 6 to 8, as the Maths teacher is unavailable before that.
For classes 3 to 5, Astro should be scheduled from Monday to Thursday only (i.e., not on Friday).
A teacher's workload is normally 6 periods per day or 36 periods per week.
A teacher's maximum workload is 48 periods per week.
A teacher should have at least one free period in the first half of the day (Periods 1-4) and one free period in the second half (Periods 5-8).
Maximum number of gaps (free periods) allowed per day and per week for a teacher.
Class Teachers should be assigned the first period of the day.
Maximum number of single gaps (isolated free periods) allowed in a teacher's schedule for selected time slots (e.g. in a Day / Week)
Maximum and minimum number of days a teacher can work per week. (Availability)
Maximum and minimum Periods for a teacher per day / Per week. (Workload Balance)
Maximum hours a teacher can work within a specific Periods Interval each day (e.g., max 2 Periods in the last 4 periods).
Maximum number of consecutive teaching periods for a teacher.
Maximum number of consecutive periods with a specific Study Format for a teacher.
A teacher may have specific "not available" time slots (e.g., meetings, personal time).
A teacher has a pair of mutually exclusive time slots (e.g., cannot teach in period 1 and period 8 on the same/particuler day every week).
Practical period of different optional subjects(Run Parallel) varies weekly frequencies: IP (4 periods/week), Physical Education (2 periods/week), Psychology (2 periods/week).
Skill subjects : Run Parallel, No of Periods varies weekly frequencies: Banking (3 periods/week), AI (4 periods/week), Taxation (4 periods/week), Mass Media (3 periods/week).
Minimum and maximum Periods per day for a teacher with a specific Study Format (e.g., Lecture, Lab).
Minimum gap required between two specific, ordered Study Formats for a teacher (e.g., must be a gap after Dance period before a Lecture).
Hobby periods require two consecutive periods for classes 6th to 9th.
Astro periods require two consecutive periods for classes 3rd to 8th.
Robotics periods require two consecutive periods for classes 6th to 8th.
Physics and Chemistry practical periods require two consecutive periods for classes 11th and 12th.
Biology practical periods require two consecutive periods for classes 11th and 12th.
A specific subject has a preferred or set of preferred rooms.
A specific Study Format (e.g., Lab) has a preferred or set of preferred rooms.
A specific subject combined with a specific Study Format has a preferred or set of preferred rooms.
A specific activity has a preferred or set of preferred rooms.
A set of activities must be scheduled in the same room if they are consecutive.
A set of activities can occupy a maximum number of different rooms.
An activity has a single preferred starting time.
An activity has a set of preferred starting times.
An activity has a set of preferred time slots.
A set of activities must have a minimum or maximum number of days between them.
An activity must be the one that ends the students' school day.
A set of activities must have the same starting time, day, or hour.
A set of activities must occupy a minimum or maximum number of time slots from a selection.
A set of activities must be scheduled consecutively, in a specific order, or grouped together.
A set of activities must not overlap in time.
A maximum or minimum number of activities from a set can be simultaneous in selected time slots.
A minimum gap is required between a set of activities.
Hobby periods for classes 6, 7, 8, and 9 must run in parallel across all sections of that grade (e.g., 6A, 6B, 6C all have Hobby at the same time).
Skill subject periods for classes 11 and 12 must run in parallel across all sections.
Optional subject periods for specific class sections (11 A/B/C/E & 12 B/C/E) must run in parallel.
Computer Lab is reserved for computer practical periods for Classes 1 to 8.
Senior Computer Lab is reserved for IP practicals (Classes 11, 12) and IT practicals (Classes 9, 10).
Robotics Lab is reserved for Robotics periods (Classes 4 to 8) and AI Skill periods (Classes 11, 12).
Biology/Chemistry Lab is reserved for Physics and Chemistry practicals for Classes 11A, 11B, 11D, 12A, 12B, and 12D.
A specific room has "not available" time slots.
A specific teacher in a specific room has "not available" time slots.
A maximum number of a set of Study Formats can be scheduled in a room per day and per week.
An activity cannot be scheduled in a room if the number of students exceeds the room's capacity.
A set of students (e.g., a class) has a specific home room.
A set of students has a set of home rooms.
A set of students has specific "not available" periods (e.g., for school assemblies).
Maximum number of days per week a set of students can attend school.
Constraint to avoid students beginning their day too often with a free period (e.g., max allowed beginnings at second hour).
Maximum number of gaps (free periods) allowed per day and per week for a set of students.
Maximum number of consecutive teaching periods for a set of students.
Maximum span of the school day for a set of students.
Minimum number of teaching periods per day for a set of students.
Maximum and minimum hours per day with a specific Study Format for a set of students.
Minimum gap required between two specific, ordered Study Formats for a set of students.
Maximum number of days per week a set of students can have a class in a specific hourly interval.
Minimum resting hours required for a set of students (e.g., overnight).
Maximum number of room changes allowed per day and per week for a set of students.
Maximum number of room changes allowed for a set of students within a specific hourly interval per day.
Minimum gap required between room changes for a set of students.
Maximum number of building changes allowed per day and per week for a set of students.
Maximum number of building changes allowed for a set of students within a specific hourly interval per day.
Minimum gap required between building changes for a set of students.

column2: Will Not Consider in this Version

column4: A teacher has a specific home room.
A teacher has a set of home rooms.
Maximum number of room changes allowed per day and per week for a teacher.
Maximum number of room changes allowed for a teacher within a specific hourly interval per day.
A teacher cannot work on #Days(25) consecutive days (e.g., must have a day off in between).
Maximum number of days per week a teacher can work within a specific hourly interval.
Minimum resting hours required for a teacher (e.g., between end of day and next start).
Minimum gap required between room changes for a teacher.
Maximum number of building changes allowed per day and per week for a teacher.
Maximum number of building changes allowed for a teacher within a specific hourly interval per day.
Minimum gap required between building changes for a teacher.
